messageBody:
On 13 May 2006, at 11:46, Michael Everson wrote:
OK... make a case... why should Quickscript be in Unicode?

I agree with amd64_hacker's points.  The usefulness of having Quickscript in Unicode would be mixed-mode documents combining latin characters with quickscript and other alternative writing systems.  A separate encoding would enable such tools as Quickscript spell-checking and dictionaries to live alongside with traditional English orthography.  I also think that it would enable some more exploration with Quickscript fonts than has been tried so far: fonts with combining glyphs to emulate the flowing nature of senior Quickscript.

These are all benefits that the Quickscript community (us) would receive from QS being part of the Unicode standard.  What would be the advantage to the Unicode consortium, or at least other parties?  At a basic level, we would have to assume an interest in English spelling reformation, or at least in alternate writing systems.  This is consistent with scripts such as Bopomofo for Mandarin and Shavian for English already being included in the Unicode standard.  I would argue that Quickscript is at least historically significant in the literature for spelling reformation; and I think that the people in this group are interested in spreading its use more widely.  (I see that the Quickscript Yahoo group "Read_Alphabet" is in fact much larger--though quieter--than the Shavian group "shawalphabet": 298 vs. 82 members.)

One argument against Quickscript would be the lack of any formal published works using it.  There is no Androcles and the Lion in Quickscript.  However, I think this is something that can and will be addressed in the future.  The task of translating existing documents is getting easier, especially with increasing access electronic public domain texts and machine-translation tools such as the perl scripts that amd64_hacker recently posted.  Moreover, there are already some attempts at creating a mixed TO and Quickscript lesson book in the files section of this site: Unicode would help this project immensely and it in turn would help spread the knowledge (and perhaps usage as well) of Quickscript!

The most important reason for me personally is that I think Quickscript (or any alternative writing system) must be machine readable if it is to be useful going into the future.  Computers are how we store and process almost all information now.  Though it was designed to be easy to write by hand, I think Quickscript also presents other benefits over  Latin-alphabet English and even Shavian spelling: conciseness (in its abbreviated words), clarity (in its sound-based approach), and readability (with related letters more differentiated than in Shavian).

oliver
